title: Job Chapter 31 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Job chapter 31 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Job Chapter 31 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Job Chapter 31.

questions.question: According to Job 31:1, what kind of covenant did Job make?
questions.correctAnswer: A covenant with his eyes
questions.explanation: Job 31:1 states, 'I made a covenant with mine eyes; why then should I think upon a maid?' indicating the covenant was with his eyes.

questions.question: In Job 31:3, what is said to be the consequence for workers of iniquity?
questions.correctAnswer: Destruction and strange punishment
questions.explanation: Job 31:3 says, 'Is not destruction to the wicked? and a strange punishment to the workers of iniquity?'

questions.question: What does Job ask to be weighed in, according to Job 31:6?
questions.correctAnswer: An even balance
questions.explanation: Job 31:6 requests, 'Let me be weighed in an even balance, that God may know mine integrity.'

questions.question: True or False: Job 31:15 states that God made Job and his servant in the womb.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 31:15 says, 'Did not he that made me in the womb make him? and did not one fashion us in the womb?', confirming both were made by God in the womb.

questions.question: According to Job 31:16, whom did Job say he must not withhold from their desire?
questions.correctAnswer: The poor
questions.explanation: Job 31:16 states, 'If I have withheld the poor from their desire, or have caused the eyes of the widow to fail;' showing concern for the poor.

questions.question: What would Job say if his land and furrows complained against him, according to Job 31:38-39?
options: He ate its fruits without paying
questions.correctAnswer: He ate its fruits without paying
questions.explanation: Job 31:38-39 questions if he ate the land's fruits without money or caused owners to lose their life.

questions.question: True or False: Job 31:32 says the stranger lodged in the street because Job's doors were closed.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 31:32 says, 'The stranger did not lodge in the street: but I opened my doors to the traveller,' showing Job welcomed strangers.

questions.question: According to Job 31:24, what did Job say he did NOT make his hope?
questions.correctAnswer: Gold
questions.explanation: Job 31:24 states, 'If I have made gold my hope, or have said to the fine gold, Thou art my confidence;' meaning he did not trust in gold.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Job 31:4: 'Doth not he see my ways, and count all my ______?'
questions.correctAnswer: steps
questions.explanation: Job 31:4 says, 'Doth not he see my ways, and count all my steps?', emphasizing God's awareness of Job's actions.

questions.question: What does Job say would happen if he had walked with vanity or hastened to deceit (Job 31:5-8)?
options: Let another eat what he sowed and his offspring be rooted out
He would be blessed with many children
questions.correctAnswer: Let another eat what he sowed and his offspring be rooted out
questions.explanation: Job 31:7-8 says if he walked with vanity or deceit, then let him sow and another eat, and his offspring be rooted out.

questions.question: True or False: Job 31:30 states that Job allowed his mouth to sin by wishing a curse on his enemy.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 31:30 says, 'Neither have I suffered my mouth to sin by wishing a curse to his soul,' meaning he did not wish curses.

questions.question: According to Job 31:9-10, what punishment does Job say he deserves if his heart was deceived by a woman?
options: Let his wife grind for another
Let him be struck with illness
questions.correctAnswer: Let his wife grind for another
questions.explanation: Job 31:9-10 says if his heart was deceived by a woman, then let his wife grind unto another and others bow down upon her.

questions.question: What would Job's reaction be if he had rejoiced at the destruction of his enemy (Job 31:29)?
options: He would be guilty of sin
questions.correctAnswer: He would be guilty of sin
questions.explanation: Job 31:29 says, 'If I rejoiced at the destruction of him that hated me,' implying this would be sinful.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Job 31:35: 'Oh that one would hear me! behold, my desire is, that the Almighty would ______ me.'
questions.correctAnswer: answer
questions.explanation: Job 31:35 states, 'Oh that one would hear me! behold, my desire is, that the Almighty would answer me,' showing Job seeks God's response.

questions.question: According to Job 31:22, what would happen to Job's arm if he lifted his hand against the fatherless?
options: It would fall from his shoulder and be broken
questions.correctAnswer: It would fall from his shoulder and be broken
questions.explanation: Job 31:22 says, 'Then let mine arm fall from my shoulder blade, and mine arm be broken from the bone,' if he harmed the fatherless.

medium.title: Job Chapter 31 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Job Chapter 31 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Job 31:1 teach us about dealing with temptation and purity in thought?
options: By making a covenant with the eyes to avoid lustful thoughts
By focusing only on outward appearance
questions.correctAnswer: By making a covenant with the eyes to avoid lustful thoughts
questions.explanation: Job 31:1 shows Job's commitment to purity by making a covenant with his eyes to avoid lustful thoughts, teaching us the importance of controlling what we allow ourselves to think about. This is supported by verses Job 31:7 and Job 31:27, which warn against following the eyes and secret enticement.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with integrity in their work. According to Job 31:6, how can they seek to maintain integrity?
options: By being weighed in an even balance before God
questions.correctAnswer: By being weighed in an even balance before God
questions.explanation: Job 31:6 teaches that integrity is measured before God’s perfect standard, asking to be weighed in an even balance. This encourages honesty and righteousness in work, supported by Job 31:4 and Job 31:23 about God seeing and fearing His judgment.

questions.question: How does Job 31:16-17 illustrate biblical generosity and care for the vulnerable?
options: By not withholding from the poor or causing the widow's eyes to fail
By focusing only on personal wealth
By ignoring the needs of others
questions.correctAnswer: By not withholding from the poor or causing the widow's eyes to fail
questions.explanation: These verses emphasize the responsibility to provide for the poor, widows, and fatherless, showing generosity and compassion as key virtues. Job 31:19-20 also reinforce caring for those in need by providing clothing and warmth.

questions.question: What does Job 31:12 teach us about the consequences of sin and iniquity?
options: Sin is like a consuming fire that destroys growth
Sin can be ignored if hidden
questions.correctAnswer: Sin is like a consuming fire that destroys growth
questions.explanation: Job 31:12 compares sin to fire that consumes and destroys all increase, illustrating the destructive nature of iniquity not only on the sinner but on their legacy, supported by Job 31:11 and Job 31:33 about punishment and hiding sin.

questions.question: Based on Job 31:13-15, how should one treat servants and those under their care?
options: With fairness and recognition of their shared creation by God
questions.correctAnswer: With fairness and recognition of their shared creation by God
questions.explanation: Job acknowledges that his servants are made by the same God as himself (verses 14-15), teaching fairness and respect for all people regardless of status. This reflects humility and justice in relationships.

questions.question: How does Job 31:24-25 warn against misplaced trust and contentment?
options: It warns against making gold one's hope or rejoicing only in wealth
It encourages accumulating as much wealth as possible
It says wealth brings true joy
questions.correctAnswer: It warns against making gold one's hope or rejoicing only in wealth
questions.explanation: Job cautions against placing confidence in wealth (gold) or rejoicing solely because of material gain, emphasizing contentment and trust in God instead. This is supported by Job 31:26-28 about not denying God above.

questions.question: A fellow believer is tempted to rejoice at the misfortune of an enemy. What biblical truth does Job 31:29-30 teach about this attitude?
options: Do not rejoice at the destruction of an enemy nor curse them
It's acceptable to wish harm on enemies
Rejoicing in evil is a sign of strength
Ignoring enemies is the best response
questions.correctAnswer: Do not rejoice at the destruction of an enemy nor curse them
questions.explanation: Job states he did not rejoice at his enemy's destruction nor sin with his mouth by cursing him, teaching forgiveness and love for neighbors even when wronged, consistent with Christian humility and mercy.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 31:32, Job was hospitable and opened his doors to travelers.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 31:32 clearly states that the stranger did not lodge in the street because Job opened his doors to the traveler, showing hospitality as a Christian virtue.

questions.question: True or False: Job 31:34 shows that Job was afraid to speak out against wrongdoing because of fear of the multitude.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 31:34 says he did not keep silence out of fear or contempt of families, indicating courage and boldness in righteousness, not fear.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Job 31:7 shows that if Job's heart followed his eyes and any _____ cleaved to his hands, he would accept the consequences.
questions.correctAnswer: blot
questions.explanation: Job 31:7 states that if any blot (stain or sin) cleaved to his hands because his heart followed his eyes, he would accept punishment, showing accountability and integrity.

questions.question: How does Job 31:9-10 instruct believers regarding faithfulness in marriage?
options: It condemns deceit and unfaithfulness with a serious warning
It allows for leniency in marital vows
questions.correctAnswer: It condemns deceit and unfaithfulness with a serious warning
questions.explanation: These verses warn against being deceived by a woman or laying wait at a neighbor’s door, demonstrating the importance of marital faithfulness and warning of severe consequences for infidelity (Job 31:11-12).

questions.question: According to Job 31:21-22, what does Job say would happen if he lifted his hand against the fatherless?
options: Let his arm fall from his shoulder and be broken
questions.correctAnswer: Let his arm fall from his shoulder and be broken
questions.explanation: Job 31:21-22 states that if he harmed the fatherless, he wished severe physical consequences on himself, reflecting strong protection of the vulnerable as a biblical virtue.

questions.question: How does Job 31:35-37 express a desire for divine justice and personal accountability?
options: Job wishes the Almighty would answer him and that his adversary had written a book to declare his innocence
Job wants to hide his faults
questions.correctAnswer: Job wishes the Almighty would answer him and that his adversary had written a book to declare his innocence
questions.explanation: These verses show Job’s desire for an open and honest confrontation with God and his adversary, emphasizing transparency, accountability, and trust in divine justice.

questions.question: What lesson about honesty in business is taught in Job 31:38-39?
options: Do not eat the fruits of the land without paying for them or cause loss to the owners
It's acceptable to take advantage in business
One should ignore the rights of others
questions.correctAnswer: Do not eat the fruits of the land without paying for them or cause loss to the owners
questions.explanation: Job 31:38-39 stresses the importance of paying for what one consumes and not causing harm to others’ property, teaching integrity and honesty in stewardship and business dealings.

questions.question: How does Job 31:4-5 reinforce the concept of personal accountability before God?
options: God sees all ways and counts every step, holding us accountable
We can hide our sins from God
God does not care about our actions
questions.correctAnswer: God sees all ways and counts every step, holding us accountable
questions.explanation: These verses affirm that God observes every action and thought, encouraging believers to live with integrity and accountability, supported also by Job 31:23.

hard.title: Job Chapter 31 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Job Chapter 31.

questions.question: In Job 31:1, Job states he made a covenant with his eyes. What is the primary significance of this covenant in the context of ancient Near Eastern morality?
options: To avoid lustful thoughts and maintain purity
To honor the gods with his vision
To meditate daily on the Law
questions.correctAnswer: To avoid lustful thoughts and maintain purity
questions.explanation: Job 31:1 highlights Job's commitment to restrain his eyes from looking lustfully at a woman, reflecting an ancient Near Eastern value of personal integrity and sexual purity.

questions.question: Job asks in Job 31:2 about the portion and inheritance of God from above. What theological theme does this question emphasize?
options: The covenant relationship between God and Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereignty and human stewardship
questions.explanation: Job 31:2 questions what portion humans can claim from God, emphasizing God's sovereign ownership and the idea that humans are stewards rather than owners.

questions.question: According to Job 31:6, what metaphor does Job use to describe the judgment of his integrity?
questions.correctAnswer: An even balance
questions.explanation: Job 31:6 uses the metaphor of an even balance (a scale) to express his desire for fair and just evaluation of his integrity by God.

questions.question: In verses 9 and 10, Job describes a specific sin involving a woman. What ancient legal or cultural principle is Job appealing to when he says, 'Then let my wife grind unto another'?
options: The law of the Nazirite vow
questions.correctAnswer: The principle of reciprocal retribution
questions.explanation: Job 31:9-10 invokes the principle of reciprocal punishment common in ancient Near Eastern law, implying that if he sinned with another woman, his wife should be treated similarly.

questions.question: What is the significance of Job’s reference to making gold his hope in Job 31:24 in relation to Israelite wisdom literature?
options: It contrasts reliance on wealth with trust in God
It endorses wealth as a sign of divine blessing
It encourages accumulation of riches for temple offerings
It symbolizes the covenantal promise of prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: It contrasts reliance on wealth with trust in God
questions.explanation: Job 31:24 reflects a common theme in wisdom literature where reliance on material wealth is contrasted with faithfulness to God, warning against idolatry of riches.

questions.question: How does Job’s plea in Job 31:35, 'Oh that one would hear me!' reflect the ancient practice of legal proceedings or covenant lawsuits found in the Hebrew Bible?
options: It resembles a covenant lawsuit (rib) where the accused calls for a heavenly witness
It is a poetic lament typical of lament psalms
It imitates prophetic denunciations against Israel
It parallels the priestly intercession rituals
questions.correctAnswer: It resembles a covenant lawsuit (rib) where the accused calls for a heavenly witness
questions.explanation: Job 31:35’s language echoes the ancient Near Eastern covenant lawsuit motif in which one calls on God as a witness to vindicate their righteousness.

questions.question: True or False: In Job 31:15, Job acknowledges a shared divine creation with his servants, implying an early understanding of human equality before God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 31:15 states that the same God who made Job also made his servants, highlighting a theological recognition of shared human dignity and equality before God.

questions.question: In Job 31:23, what is the nature of Job’s fear of destruction from God and how does it shape his behavior?
options: A reverential fear that motivates moral integrity
A paralyzing terror that causes avoidance of society
A superstitious fear leading to ritual sacrifices
A political fear of divine punishment for rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: A reverential fear that motivates moral integrity
questions.explanation: Job 31:23 shows that Job’s fear of God’s destruction is tied to reverence and awe, which motivates him to live righteously and avoid sin.

questions.question: In the chiasmic structure suggested by Job 31, what thematic element is mirrored between verses 8-10 and verses 38-40?
options: The consequences of injustice on offspring and land
The purity of speech and silence
The relationship between servant and master
The role of divine blessings in prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: The consequences of injustice on offspring and land
questions.explanation: Job 31:8-10 discusses consequences affecting offspring due to sin, mirrored by 31:38-40 where injustice causes the land to cry out, highlighting the theme of repercussions of moral failure.

questions.question: Which Hebrew term translated as 'iniquity' in Job 31:3 and 31:28 carries a deeper connotation of rebellion against divine order?
questions.correctAnswer: Avon
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'Avon' used in Job 31:3 and 31:28 denotes not only sin but also a moral distortion or rebellion against God’s covenantal order.

questions.question: How does Job’s concern for the poor and fatherless in verses 16-22 reflect the socio-religious obligations in ancient Israelite culture?
options: It reflects the Torah laws about justice and care for the vulnerable
It is unique to Job’s personal ethics without cultural precedent
It mirrors pagan Near Eastern customs of patronage
It anticipates New Testament teachings exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the Torah laws about justice and care for the vulnerable
questions.explanation: Job 31:16-22 reflects the cultural and religious mandates found in Torah, commanding care for the poor, widow, and orphan as a key aspect of righteousness.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Job 31:27-28, where Job describes being 'secretly enticed' and 'kissing his hand,' and how does it function in the passage?
options: Irony, to emphasize the absurdity of idolatry
Simile, to compare temptation to a physical kiss
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor, denoting secret apostasy
questions.explanation: Job 31:27-28 uses metaphor to describe a covert turning away from God, equating secret enticement and kissing the hand with idolatry and denial of God.

questions.question: In Job 31:32, Job contrasts the treatment of strangers with that of the men of his tabernacle. What cultural virtue is Job emphasizing here?
questions.correctAnswer: Hospitality towards travelers
questions.explanation: Job 31:32 emphasizes the ancient Near Eastern and Israelite virtue of hospitality, showing that Job opened his doors to strangers rather than leaving them to lodge in the streets.

questions.question: True or False: Job’s statement in 31:33 about 'covering transgressions as Adam' alludes to a concept of inherited guilt or original sin that is later developed in Christian theology.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 31:33 alludes to Adam’s act of hiding sin, which foreshadows later theological concepts of original sin and human guilt introduced in Christian doctrine.

questions.question: Job’s willingness to 'take it upon my shoulder, and bind it as a crown to me' in Job 31:36 can be interpreted as what literary or theological motif?
options: Acceptance of responsibility and honor in vindication
A metaphor for bearing physical burdens
A ritual of kingship and divine right
A vow of silence before God
questions.correctAnswer: Acceptance of responsibility and honor in vindication
questions.explanation: Job 31:36 uses the image of binding a book as a crown to symbolize embracing the burden of proof and confidently asserting his righteousness before God.

theological.title: Job Chapter 31 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Job Chapter 31 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What covenant did Job claim to have made with his eyes?
options: To not look lustfully upon a maid
To see all things with clarity
To avoid looking at the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: To not look lustfully upon a maid
questions.explanation: Job 31:1 states, 'I made a covenant with mine eyes; why then should I think upon a maid?' This expresses Job's commitment to purity, paralleling teachings such as Jesus’ exhortation in Matthew 5:28 against lust and the call for holiness in 1 Thessalonians 4:3-5.

questions.question: According to Job, what is the consequence for the wicked and workers of iniquity?
questions.correctAnswer: Destruction and strange punishment
questions.explanation: Job 31:3 declares, 'Is not destruction to the wicked? and a strange punishment to the workers of iniquity?' This aligns with biblical doctrine on divine judgment as seen in Romans 6:23 and Psalm 1:6.

questions.question: How does Job describe God’s awareness of his actions?
options: God sees his ways and counts all his steps
God is unaware of human deeds
questions.correctAnswer: God sees his ways and counts all his steps
questions.explanation: Job 31:4 says, 'Doth not he see my ways, and count all my steps?' This highlights God's omniscience, consistent with Psalm 139:1-4 and Hebrews 4:13.

questions.question: What does Job request if he has walked in vanity or deceit?
options: To be weighed in an even balance for integrity
To be hidden from God's sight
questions.correctAnswer: To be weighed in an even balance for integrity
questions.explanation: Job 31:6 states, 'Let me be weighed in an even balance, that God may know mine integrity.' This reflects the biblical theme of divine judgment of the heart, as in Proverbs 16:11 and 1 Samuel 16:7.

questions.question: What punishment does Job accept if his heart has been deceived by a woman or if he has lain in wait at his neighbor's door?
options: Let my wife grind unto another and others bow down upon her
Let me be cast out of the community
Let me be struck with blindness
Let me lose all my possessions
questions.correctAnswer: Let my wife grind unto another and others bow down upon her
questions.explanation: Job 31:9-10 expresses this severe self-imposed penalty, emphasizing the seriousness of marital fidelity and neighborly respect, consistent with commandments in Exodus 20:14 and Leviticus 19:18.

questions.question: How does Job view despising the cause of his servants when they contended with him?
options: As a sin that he must answer for before God
As a necessary exercise of authority
questions.correctAnswer: As a sin that he must answer for before God
questions.explanation: Job 31:13-14 reveals Job's concern that injustice toward servants is accountable to God, who made both master and servant (Job 31:15), reflecting biblical calls for justice such as Deuteronomy 24:14-15 and James 5:4.

questions.question: What reason does Job give for caring for the poor, widows, and orphans?
options: Because God made them equally in the womb with him
Because it brought him public honor
Because it was a social custom
questions.correctAnswer: Because God made them equally in the womb with him
questions.explanation: Job 31:15-18 emphasize that God created both Job and his servants, underscoring human equality and the call to compassionate justice, evident also in Isaiah 1:17 and James 1:27.

questions.question: What does Job say should happen if he has eaten his morsel alone without sharing with the fatherless?
options: He has committed a serious wrong
He will be blessed with abundance
He will be praised for self-reliance
questions.correctAnswer: He has committed a serious wrong
questions.explanation: Job 31:17 connects selfish nourishment with sin, highlighting social responsibility, consistent with Proverbs 22:9 and Luke 3:11.

questions.question: What severe consequence does Job call upon himself if he has lifted his hand against the fatherless?
options: Let mine arm fall from my shoulder and be broken
Let me be exiled from the land
Let me be struck with blindness
questions.correctAnswer: Let mine arm fall from my shoulder and be broken
questions.explanation: Job 31:22 shows Job's earnest self-judgment for mistreating the vulnerable, echoing the protective commands for orphans and widows in Exodus 22:22-24 and Psalm 82:3.

questions.question: What does Job say about making gold his hope or confidence?
options: It would be an iniquity punished by the judge
It is a sign of blessing
questions.correctAnswer: It would be an iniquity punished by the judge
questions.explanation: Job 31:24-28 condemns placing trust in wealth rather than God, which reflects biblical warnings in 1 Timothy 6:10 and Psalm 62:10 about the dangers of idolatry and misplaced confidence.

questions.question: How does Job say he has treated strangers and travelers?
options: He opened his doors to them
questions.correctAnswer: He opened his doors to them
questions.explanation: Job 31:32 states, 'The stranger did not lodge in the street: but I opened my doors to the traveller,' highlighting hospitality as a righteous act, consistent with Hebrews 13:2 and Genesis 18:1-8.

questions.question: What does Job mean by covering his transgressions as Adam did?
questions.correctAnswer: Hiding iniquity in his bosom
questions.explanation: Job 31:33 references Adam’s attempt to hide sin (Genesis 3:7-10), contrasting with biblical calls to confess and repent (1 John 1:9; Proverbs 28:13).

questions.question: What is Job's desire regarding the Almighty's response to his words?
options: That the Almighty would answer him
That God would punish him immediately
That God would forget his complaints
questions.correctAnswer: That the Almighty would answer him
questions.explanation: Job 31:35 expresses Job’s longing for divine dialogue, reflecting biblical themes of seeking God’s presence and justice as in Psalm 27:7 and Isaiah 1:18.

questions.question: What symbolic action does Job say he would do if his adversary wrote a book against him?
options: Take it upon his shoulder and bind it as a crown
questions.correctAnswer: Take it upon his shoulder and bind it as a crown
questions.explanation: Job 31:36 reveals Job’s willingness to bear accusations honorably, symbolizing perseverance and integrity, paralleling Christ who bore our sins (Isaiah 53:4; 1 Peter 2:23).

questions.question: What curse does Job wish upon himself if he has eaten the fruits of his land without payment or caused loss to the owners?
options: Let thistles grow instead of wheat and cockle instead of barley
Let his crops flourish and prosper
Let his land produce twice as much
questions.correctAnswer: Let thistles grow instead of wheat and cockle instead of barley
questions.explanation: Job 31:39-40 articulates a curse for unjust gain, reflecting Old Testament principles of restitution such as Leviticus 19:13 and Proverbs 11:1.
